title: [h1-2102] [Yaworski's Broskis] Suspected overcharge and chargebacks in PoS

profile.name: Shopify
profile.about: Shopify is a multi-channel commerce platform that helps people sell online, in-store, and everywhere in between.

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:

NOTE: This one need verification from the side of Shopify as we can't set up a real payment GW or check the logs of the test one

When checking out in PoS and paying with credit card, it is possible to manipulate numbers in the end request to overcharge a client (charge more than the item price) and to send money to the client from the store

```json 
{
    "payment": {
        "session_id": "9",
        "amount_in": 1.09,       <<<<<
        "amount_rounding": 0,    <<<<<<<
        "amount": 1.09,   <<<<<<<
        "device_id": 2131722262,
        "unique_token": "xxx",
        "amount_tip": 0,
        "card_source": "manual",
        "auto_finalize": false,
        "user_id": 64582418454,
        "amount_out": 0,     <<<<<
        "location_id": 52512587798,
        "charge": true
    }
}
```

There are four  values which interest us here: `amount`, `amount_in`, `amount_rounding` and `amount_out`. Those control how much the client is charged. They should follow the formula `amount = amount_in - amount_rounding - amount_out`. `amount`  should always remain the price of the cart.
 `amount_in` is how much is charged from the client. `amount_out` is how much is taken from the shop. Looks like `amount_rounding` is a number which is not taken from anyone and is in fact some in-fact-rounding-value.

Some of these values allow negative values which broadens our possibilities. Let's see how it works. 

## Steps To Reproduce:
You would need PoS in your show installed and installed on your phone (I used iphone with jailbreak to proxy data into Burp). https://apps.shopify.com/shopify-pos.

> NOTE: I have used the test store to work with the payments. In real case this might work differently, but since I couldn't find a way to approve that, I decided to submit it nonetheless.

Create a new order with an item. I will be using a $1.09 dummy item from my shop. Now start the checkout process and select credit card as a payment source.

{F1176221}

{F1176222}

Enter card details and be ready to intercept this request.
{F1176223}

We are looking for the similar `payments.json` request:
  
{F1176220}

```http
POST /admin/api/unstable/checkouts/5788adb325c4824f193d08daf474f21a/payments.json HTTP/1.1
Host: c0rv4x2.myshopify.com
...

{"payment":{"amount":1.09,"user_id":64582418454,"amount_rounding":0,"charge":true,"card_source":"manual","amount_out":0,"location_id":52512587798,"session_id":"east-fbc4aa9a711b9a5f13a0a76e9bd7c879","amount_tip":0,"amount_in":1.09,"auto_finalize":false,"device_id":2131722262,"unique_token":"4DA811C1-4824-4451-B576-290137624B1A"}}
```

Change `amount_in` to `2.09` (1 USD more than the current price) `amount_rounding` to `-1.0` (retracting that one dollar to make our equation from the begging of this report true).

```http
POST /admin/api/unstable/checkouts/5788adb325c4824f193d08daf474f21a/payments.json HTTP/1.1
Host: c0rv4x2.myshopify.com
...

{"payment":{"amount":1.09,"user_id":64582418454,"amount_rounding":-1.0,"charge":true,"card_source":"manual","amount_out":0,"location_id":52512587798,"session_id":"east-fbc4aa9a711b9a5f13a0a76e9bd7c879","amount_tip":0,"amount_in":2.09,"auto_finalize":false,"device_id":2131722262,"unique_token":"4DA811C1-4824-4451-B576-290137624B1A"}}
```

{F1176224}

## Similar behaviour

Similar behaviour is possible if we set `amount_out` to a non negative value (which would mean the shop is losing money).

## Impact

Potentially manipulate customers and shops money without their conscent

activities.message: Hey, I have asked Pete to check the logs and he didn't find anything suspicious. So this doesn't work with credit cards at the moment, but it DOES work with gift cards. So if that is fine, could you keep this report open for some time till I get more details?

Hey @c0rv4x

Are you still needing to review this in the mean time?

Hey @orangeband,

No, not yet. Sorry for the confusing. 
I have managed to prove that the problem exists, but haven't written the details yet. I will ping you here or on slack once done
Thanks for the update. I'll move the report to NMI; once done, you can provide the information to the report. Thanks!

Hey @orangeband 

Sorry for the delay. I was able to verify the overcharge. Please follow this message for details (the original message can be ignored)

You would need an officially approved Shopify Payments account to be able to perform overcharge from the credit card. However you can also perform the same vulnerability with the exact same workflow but with gift card!

You would need PoS app installed on a jailbroken device to be able to replay this vulnerability: https://apps.shopify.com/shopify-pos

1. Log in to the store with the approved payments system and start checking any item. 
2. Select Credit Card payment - my products price is CAD 0.5
{F1177394}
3. Enter you credit card and intercept the request after you push `Charge` button on the top left
3. You would need to find a request like this one: 

```http
POST /admin/api/unstable/checkouts/35855b1eb0147072e1ab724780a56576/payments.json HTTP/1.1
Host: <xx>.myshopify.com
...

{"payment":{"amount":0.5,"unique_token":"<xx>","device_id":3721920671,"amount_in":0.5,"amount_tip":0,"auto_finalize":false,"session_id":"e<xx>","amount_out":0,"user_id":69440700575,"location_id":48455581855,"card_source":"manual","charge":true,"amount_rounding":0}}
```

4. Change `amount_in` and `amount` values to 1.5 and issue the request:  you will charged 1.5
{F1177399}

Hey @c0rv4x

I believe this to be a false positive. I was able to reproduce this and get the endpoints via the android app. However, when I did modify the request amount to another value, although it reflected within the app, the receipt I emailed still showed the original price with no change. Did the change also reflect in the receipt when you sent one to yourself? It seems like it may be a UI reflection but nothing more.

Thanks,
@orangeband

Hey!

This actually worked for me and the change is shown in the SMS receipt on the picture. Look for 1.5 CAD

Thanks!

Hi @c0rv4x,
Thanks again for your report! 
We're awarding a $500 bounty for this issue. Please find below our rationale generated using our [CVSS calculator](https://shopify.github.io/appsec/cvss_calculator/). We have set the Attack Vector to Physical because the victim would need to make a purchase in the store. This issue has a High Attack Complexity because you would need to convince the buyer to come into your store, purchase an item, and view the POS interface with the amount (this POS view is typically intended only for the merchant). The issue has a Low Integrity impact, as this is limited to one transaction and only affects buyer's swiping their credit card. 

## Base Score CVSS:3.0/AV:P/AC:H/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:L/A:N 2.0
## Environment: Core

#### Attack Complexity: H
* Specific conditions or measurable effort to exploit?: Yes

#### Privileges Required: N
* Requires privileged account (not self-registered)?: No

#### User Interaction: N
* Requires victim to perform some action during exploit?: No

#### Scope: U
* Can the attacker impact a separate service?: No

#### Confidentiality: N
* How much data could be accessed?: None

#### Integrity: L
* How much data could be changed?: Some
* How much of Shopify is impacted?: Some

#### Availability: N
* Level of disruption to network service?: None
Thank you for your report, keep up the great work!
Thank you for your report, keep up the great work!
Thank you for your report, keep up the great work!
Thank you for your report, keep up the great work!
Thank you for your report, keep up the great work!

activities.message:
Hey @c0rv4x, thanks again for the report.

I am reaching out to inform you that we have implemented a fix for this issue, and it is no longer reproducible. Now, if the `amount` is greater than the order total when processing a credit card, we will fail the payment request. As such, I will resolve this report.

Cheers.
Sure, let's disclose this one! Thank you
